reasoning:
First and foremost, Amazon lies outside my circle of competence. It’s part‐retail business, part‐cloud technology giant, and I’ve long steered clear of complex tech models where capital requirements, regulatory shifts and rapid innovation can turn a future cash‐cow into a money pit. 

When I look at Amazon’s moat, I see pockets of pricing power in AWS and network effects in Prime, but its inconsistent ROE – only 0 out of 10 years above 15% – tells me the business hasn’t delivered the durable, double‐digit returns I prize. Indeed, while operating margins of 30% hint at pricing strength, the broader retail arm runs on razor‐thin margins and intense competition from the likes of Walmart and Alibaba.

Management under Bezos and Jassy has shown visionary long‐term thinking, plowing every dollar of free cash flow back into expansion rather than rewarding shareholders through buybacks or dividends. That aggressive capital allocation has built scale, but it’s come at the expense of owner earnings – today minus $1,725 million – which I need to see in healthy, predictable form before I’ll step in.

Financially, Amazon’s debt‐to‐equity ratio of 3.1 is far higher than I’m comfortable with in a business without a fortress balance sheet. Its return on invested capital is a meager 0.6%, and the erratic earnings growth shows a business still finding its footing, not the steady compounding machine I seek.

Putting a valuation on Amazon using a three‐stage DCF produces a negative intrinsic value. A margin of safety of minus 1.16 tells me the market price far exceeds the business’s economic worth under reasonable assumptions.

Looking twenty years out, I’m not convinced Amazon will exhibit the fortress‐like predictability of Coca-Cola or the consumer pull of See’s Candies. Its capital intensity and competitive pressures pose too many unknowns. 

Compared to the businesses in my portfolio – where I happily own wonderful franchises at fair prices and hold them forever – Amazon fails on every score: circle of competence, consistent returns, financial strength and valuation. So my verdict is clear: bearish.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 2.5%; High debt to equity ratio of 3.1; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 281.0% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Strong and stable operating margins (avg: 29.0%) indicate pricing power moat

book_value_analysis.details: Good book value per share growth pattern

management_analysis.details: No significant new stock issuance detected; No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (8.0%, 5y), Stage 2 (4.0%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
